p: Bianco and Demers, in a publication about trends in compensation for occupational cancer in Ontario, Canada, noted that lung cancer was the most frequently compensated occupational cancer, especially in the construction, manufacturing, and mining industries [ 35]. Occupational lung cancer in Korea, reported by Yeon-Soon Ahn and Kyong Sook Jeong, was primarily associated with manufacturing and construction work and were the most common occupations compensating for lung cancer [ 19]. Both studies indicated that asbestos was responsible for the elevated risks of lung cancer, especially among construction workers.
